questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to 2 days of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea.  Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 16/min. There is abdominal tenderness with no rebound or guarding. Guaiac-positive bloody stools are detected on rectal examination. Stool cultures reveal an Escherichia coli strain that does not produce glucuronidase and does not ferment sorbitol on sorbitol-containing MacConkey agar. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the toxin specific to these bacteria?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Inactivation of 60S ribosomal subunits

questions.text: A person presents with pneumonia. His sputum was sent for culture. The bacterium obtained showed gram positive cocci in chains on microscopy and alpha haemolytic colonies on sheep agar. Which of the following will help in confirming the diagnosis?

On physical examination, external rotation of the right shoulder against resistance is painful, but there is no weakness. MRI reveals near complete tear of the right infraspinatus muscle. The absence of weakness in this patient is best explained by compensatory hypertrophy of which of the following muscles?
Which of the following muscle is supplied by the nucleus present beneath the area marked by the arrow in adjoining image?

Two months after receiving lung transplant, he developed pulmonary symptoms and was diagnosed as having bilateral diffuse interstitial pulmonary pneumonitis and bronchiolitis. Which of the following etiological agent is responsible in this condition?

During retrieval of the fish bone, a nerve deep to the mucosa overlying the recess is damaged. Which of the following is most likely to be impaired in this patient as a result of his iatrogenic injury?

A 7-year-old male child, weighing 29 kg, is brought to OPD with a category 3 wound after a dog bite. Currently, equine rabies immunoglobulin is available instead of human rabies immunoglobulin. What dosage should be given as post-exposure prophylaxis for this child?

questions.solution: Ans. B) Secretomotor to parotid gland

questions.solution: Ans. B) Cytochrome C oxidase

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statements:

 

  1. MODY3 is a defect in HNF1A
  2. N-acetyl cysteine acts by replenishing stores of intrahepatic glutathione
  3. Xeroderma pigmentosa is a defect in base excision repair
  4. Defective fumaryl-acetoacetate hydrolase enzyme is associated with type 2 tyrosinemia

questions.text: Match the following:
Identify the layer of the retina.

A 35-year-old patient arrives at the hospital emergency department presenting with gastrointestinal distress. The patient complains of severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. During the physical examination, the medical team observes that the patient's stools emit an unusual faint glow. The patient appears disoriented and fatigued. The medical history reveals that the patient attended a local festival the previous day and consumed various food items there. The following exposures might be contributing to which substance toxication?

A newborn infant presents with diarrhoea after consuming breast milk. The infant seems comfortable when given glucose and water but exhibits abdominal cramps, flatulence and excessive crying when after feed on breast milk. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lactose intolerance

 

  • Lactose intolerance in newborns is rare but possible, especially in cases of congenital lactase deficiency. 
  • In this condition, the infant lacks the enzyme lactase, which is necessary to break down lactose, the primary sugar in breast milk. 
  • When lactose is ingested, it cannot be properly digested, leading to symptoms such as abdominal cramping, crying, lethargy, and vomiting. 
  • Tolerance to glucose and water without symptoms further supports lactose intolerance, as these substances do not contain lactose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactosemia: Although galactosemia also presents with symptoms after milk ingestion, it typically includes additional findings such as jaundice, hepatomegaly, and, if untreated, can lead to serious complications. Additionally, glucose is generally not tolerated well in galactosemia, which differentiates it from lactose intolerance.

 

Option C. Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU involves an inability to metabolize phenylalanine rather than lactose and generally does not cause symptoms specifically related to breast milk intolerance. It typically presents with developmental delay if untreated, rather than acute symptoms like vomiting after milk ingestion.

 

Option D. Maple syrup urine disease: This condition results from a defect in branched-chain amino acid metabolism, causing poor feeding and lethargy, but it does not specifically affect lactose digestion. Maple syrup urine disease also presents with a distinctive maple syrup odor in the urine, which is not mentioned in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital lactose intolerance results from a lack of lactase enzyme, leading to symptoms of abdominal cramps, vomiting, and lethargy after ingestion of lactose-containing breast milk.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with symptoms of muscle fatigue during moderate exercise. His dietary history reveals that he recently began consuming raw eggs daily as part of a high-protein regimen. Given his dietary changes, which enzyme deficiency is most likely contributing to his exercise intolerance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyruvate carboxylase

 

  • Pyruvate carboxylase is a biotin-dependent enzyme essential for gluconeogenesis, as it converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate in the mitochondria. 
  • Raw eggs contain avidin, a protein that binds biotin and prevents its absorption, leading to a biotin deficiency in individuals who consume large amounts of raw eggs. 
  • Biotin deficiency can impair pyruvate carboxylase function, resulting in symptoms like fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance due to compromised gluconeogenesis and energy production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogen phosphorylase: Glycogen phosphorylase is involved in glycogen breakdown, releasing glucose for energy, particularly during high-intensity exercise. A deficiency would result in glycogen storage diseases such as McArdle's disease, which presents with muscle cramps and myoglobinuria. However, this condition is unrelated to biotin deficiency from raw egg consumption.

 

Option B. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK): PEPCK is also crucial in gluconeogenesis, but its activity does not directly depend on biotin. Thus, a biotin deficiency would not significantly impact PEPCK activity, making it an unlikely cause of the symptoms associated with raw egg consumption.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase: Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme involved in the final step of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose in the liver. A deficiency in this enzyme is associated with Von Gierke's disease, which primarily presents with hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly. It is not affected by biotin availability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Biotin deficiency, often due to raw egg consumption, can impair pyruvate carboxylase function, leading to decreased gluconeogenesis and resulting in exercise intolerance and fatigue.

questions.text: Among the following fatty acids, which one does not belong to the omega-6 (ω6) series?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha-linolenic acid

 

  • Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) is an omega-3 (ω3) fatty acid, not an omega-6 (ω6) fatty acid. 
  • Omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids are classified based on the position of the first double bond from the methyl end of the fatty acid chain. 
  • ALA has its first double bond at the third carbon, making it part of the omega-3 series, while omega-6 fatty acids, such as arachidonic acid, gamma-linolenic acid, and linoleic acid, have their first double bond at the sixth carbon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stearidonic acid: Stearidonic acid is an omega-6 fatty acid derived from the elongation and desaturation of linoleic acid and plays a role in inflammation.

 

Option C. Arachidonic acid: Arachidonic acid is a major omega-6 fatty acid involved in producing eicosanoids, crucial for regulating inflammation and cellular signaling.

 

Option D. Dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid (DGLA): DGLA is an omega-6 fatty acid that contributes to anti-inflammatory processes and immune response, derived from the elongation of gamma-linolenic acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) is an omega-3 fatty acid, distinct from omega-6 fatty acids like arachidonic acid, gamma-linolenic acid, and linoleic acid, based on the location of the first double bond in the carbon chain.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is admitted to the hospital following a severe motor vehicle accident. Despite initial stabilization, he succumbs to his injuries three days after the incident. During the postmortem examination, bleeding is noted on the surface of the brain that does not wash away with water. Which of the following is the most likely source of this bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subarachnoid bleeding

 

  • Subarachnoid bleeding, or subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), is the accumulation of blood within the subarachnoid space, where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) normally circulates. 
  • When a person experiences head trauma, blood from damaged vessels in this space may accumulate. 
  • During a postmortem examination, blood in the subarachnoid space typically remains intact, not easily washed away by water, due to its location within the layers of the meninges. 
  • This feature of subarachnoid bleeding helps differentiate it from other types of intracranial hemorrhages, which can often be displaced by washing. 
  • Traumatic SAH is common in head injuries and is often associated with significant morbidity and mortality.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidural bleeding: Epidural hemorrhage occurs between the dura mater and the skull and is typically caused by an arterial rupture, often due to temporal bone fractures that damage the middle meningeal artery. The blood from an epidural hemorrhage is usually contained in a biconvex shape on imaging and can sometimes be washed away by water in a postmortem setting, unlike subarachnoid bleeding.

 

Option C. Subdural hematoma (SDH): Subdural hematoma occurs between the dura and arachnoid mater and is often associated with venous bleeding, particularly from bridging veins. While subdural blood can adhere to the surface of the brain, it is typically displaced more easily than subarachnoid blood during postmortem washing, which helps distinguish it from subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Intraparenchymal bleeding: Intraparenchymal or intracerebral bleeding occurs within the brain tissue itself, rather than on its surface or in the subarachnoid space. This type of hemorrhage is typically confined within the brain parenchyma and can be washed away if exposed to water during an autopsy, unlike subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage can be identified postmortem by blood that remains intact and is not washed away by water, distinguishing it from other types of intracranial bleeding.

questions.text: A 20-year-old sexual assault victim is examined in a courtroom setting described as "in camera." What does this imply about the nature of the court proceedings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed proceeding

 

  • "In camera" is a legal term used to describe a judicial proceeding that is held privately, away from the public and the media. 
  • This setting is particularly used in sensitive cases, such as those involving sexual assault, to protect the privacy and dignity of the victim. 
  • In such proceedings, only selected individuals, such as the judge, lawyers, the accused, the victim, and sometimes a few relatives of the victim, are allowed to be present.
  • This type of trial is mandated in India for all sexual assault cases to ensure the victim's confidentiality and provide a safe environment free from public scrutiny. 
  • It is not a public trial, and the general public is not allowed to attend.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open proceeding: An open proceeding is accessible to the public and media, which is not suitable for sensitive cases like sexual assault due to privacy concerns. This option is incorrect because "in camera" specifically denotes a closed proceeding.

 

Option C. Recorded in camera: This option might seem correct due to the term "camera," but it does not mean the proceedings are being recorded. "In camera" refers to the closed nature of the trial, not to any form of recording.

 

Option D. Proceedings in another place: This option incorrectly implies that the trial is conducted at a different location. However, "in camera" refers to the nature of the trial being private, not about the location of the proceedings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • "In camera" refers to a closed proceeding in court where only selected individuals are allowed to be present, ensuring the privacy of sensitive cases such as those involving sexual assault.

questions.text:
Match the following conditions to their corresponding colors of postmortem staining in forensic examinations: 

 

Conditions:

  1. Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
  2. Opium Poisoning
  3. Hydrogen Sulphide Poisoning
  4. Clostridium Perfringens Infection

 

Colors: 

  1. Bluish Green
  2. Cherry Red
  3. Bronze
  4. Black
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 – B, 2 – D, 3 – A, 4 - C

 

1. Carbon Monoxide Poisoning results in a B. Cherry Red staining due to carboxyhemoglobin that imparts a distinctive pink or red hue to the skin and mucous membranes.

 

2. Opium Poisoning causes D. Black postmortem staining, a result of the drug's impact on blood properties.

 

3. Hydrogen Sulphide Poisoning induces a  A. Bluish Green staining, reflecting its sulfide interactions with blood and other bodily tissues.

 

4. Clostridium Perfringens Infection leads to C. Bronze staining, typical in severe bacterial infections like gas gangrene that causes massive tissue necrosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

# (In Aniline Deep blue as well as Red Brown colour can occur)

questions.text: A 50-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with chronic lung infection and abscesses. Gram stain and blood agar culture findings shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia species

 

  • The images and clinical context suggest an infection with Nocardia species. Nocardia is a genus of filamentous, branching, Gram-positive bacteria that can cause chronic infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals. 
  • It often presents with pulmonary involvement and can spread to the skin and brain. 
  • In a Gram stain, Nocardia appears as branching, beaded filaments (Image a). 
  • On blood agar, it forms characteristic dry, wrinkled, white colonies (Image b). Nocardia is partially acid-fast, which helps differentiate it from other filamentous bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actinomyces species: Actinomyces is also a filamentous bacterium but is not acid-fast and is typically associated with anaerobic infections, such as cervicofacial abscesses. Actinomyces colonies have a “molar tooth” appearance, different from Nocardia.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: M. tuberculosis does not exhibit branching, filamentous morphology. Instead, it appears as acid-fast bacilli without the branching seen in Nocardia.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium leprae: M. leprae is also an acid-fast bacillus but does not form branching, filamentous structures, nor does it grow on conventional culture media like blood agar, unlike Nocardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nocardia species are branching, filamentous, partially acid-fast bacteria that form dry, wrinkled colonies on blood agar and commonly affect immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 18-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with a 2-week history of rapidly increasing swelling on his jaw, recurrent nosebleeds, weight loss, and generalized fatigue. Physical examination of the neck reveals firm, nontender lymph nodes. The mass is biopsied, the image is shown below. Which of the following best describes the genomic structure of the most likely causative virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Double-stranded linear DNA

 

  • This patient’s presentation, including rapid swelling of lymph nodes, recurrent nosebleeds, weight loss, and fatigue, is concerning for lymphoma, particularly Burkitt lymphoma. 
  • Burkitt lymphoma is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), a virus with a double-stranded linear DNA genome. 
  • EBV is known to be involved in the pathogenesis of several lymphoproliferative diseases, including Burkitt lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Double-stranded circular DNA: This is characteristic of certain viruses like the herpesvirus family (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus), but Epstein-Barr virus specifically has a linear double-stranded DNA genome, not circular.

 

Option C. Double-stranded linear RNA: Double-stranded RNA viruses are found in families like reoviruses, but they are not associated with Burkitt lymphoma or the Epstein-Barr virus.

 

Option D. Single-stranded linear RNA: Single-stranded RNA viruses (e.g., influenza virus, HIV) are not associated with Burkitt lymphoma, which is linked to EBV, a DNA virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most likely causative virus for this patient’s symptoms is Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), which has a double-stranded linear DNA genome. 
  • EBV is associated with Burkitt lymphoma and other lymphoproliferative disorders.

questions.text: A 1-year-old patient came with complaints of fever with rash but the only specific point about the patient was that rash appeared after the disappearance of fever. What is the best diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6th disease 

 

  • Patient is suffering from roseola infantum which is also known as 6th disease
  • It is caused by HHV 6>7
  • In roseola infantum fever will subside then rash will come 

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. 5th disease: It is also known as erythema infectiosum. This caused by human parvovirus B19, the characteristic appearance is slapped cheek appearance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Roseola infantum, also known as sixth disease, is a common viral infection in young children, typically caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6). 
  • It often presents with a sudden high fever followed by a distinctive rash as the fever subsides.

choices.text: 1200 mL Ringer's lactate (RL) over 12 hours
600 mL Ringer's lactate (RL) over 6 hours
900 mL Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) over 4 hours
300 mL ORS per episode of loose stool

questions.text: A 3-year-old child weighing 12 kg presents with loose motions. He is thirsty, drinks eagerly, has absent tears, and his skin pinch goes back slowly. What is the best treatment plan for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 900 mL Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) over 4 hours

 

  • The clinical signs described (thirsty, drinks eagerly, absent tears, slow skin pinch) suggest "some dehydration." 
  • According to the guidelines, children with some dehydration should receive 75 mL/kg of ORS over 4 hours. 
  • For a child weighing 12 kg, the calculation is 75 mL/kg × 12 kg = 900 mL ORS over 4 hours. 
  • This treatment plan ensures rapid and adequate rehydration to address fluid losses due to diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1200 mL RL over 12 hours: This option describes the administration of intravenous fluids, which is reserved for cases of severe dehydration or when oral rehydration is not possible. Since the child can drink and has only some dehydration, ORS is the preferred treatment.

 

Option B. 600 mL RL over 6 hours: Similar to option (a), this involves intravenous rehydration, which is unnecessary in this case. The child can be treated effectively with oral rehydration using ORS.

 

Option D. 300 mL ORS per episode of loose stool: This approach does not provide sufficient fluid replacement for the existing dehydration. It may be used for maintenance and ongoing fluid losses but does not address the initial rehydration needs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Children with some dehydration due to diarrhea should be rehydrated with oral rehydration solution (ORS) at 75 mL/kg over 4 hours. 
  • Accurate fluid replacement is essential for effective management and to prevent progression to severe dehydration.

questions.text: All of these are causes of bilious vomiting in a neonate at birth except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infantile pyloric stenosis

 

  • Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) typically presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting, but it occurs at around 4-8 weeks of age, not at birth. 
  • It results from hypertrophy of the pylorus, leading to gastric outlet obstruction. Therefore, it is not a cause of vomiting in neonates at birth.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia is a congenital obstruction of the duodenum, usually presenting with bilious vomiting within the first 24-48 hours of life. It is often associated with the "double bubble" sign on radiographs.

 

Option C. Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia also presents with bilious vomiting shortly after birth due to congenital obstruction of the jejunum, leading to intestinal obstruction. It is a cause of neonatal vomiting.

 

Option D. Meconium ileus: Meconium ileus, often associated with cystic fibrosis, is a condition where thick, sticky meconium obstructs the intestine. It presents with bilious vomiting and failure to pass meconium in the first days of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis does not present at birth but rather around 4-8 weeks of life with non-bilious vomiting. 
  • In contrast, conditions like duodenal atresia, jejunal atresia, and meconium ileus can cause vomiting in the immediate neonatal period.

choices.text: Dengavaxia protects against all four serotypes of the dengue virus.
The leprosy vaccine MIP is administered alongside a dose of Rifampicin.
Mosquirix is an available vaccine against malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.
Covishield functions as a vaccine based on the receptor-binding domain of the spike protein.

questions.text: Which of the following descriptions does not accurately match the vaccine it pertains to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Covishield functions as a vaccine based on the receptor-binding domain of the spike protein.

 

Covishield, developed by Oxford-AstraZeneca, is a viral vector vaccine, not a receptor-binding domain (RBD) proteinaceous vaccine. It uses a modified chimpanzee adenovirus to deliver genetic material, encouraging cells to produce the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein and triggering an immune response, distinct from vaccines that directly use protein subunits of the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Correct. Dengavaxia is a tetravalent vaccine designed to protect against all four dengue virus serotypes.

 

Option B: Correct. MIP vaccine for leprosy is typically administered with Rifampicin to improve efficacy.

 

Option C: Correct. Mosquirix (RTS,S) is the first and only malaria vaccine approved for use against Plasmodium falciparum, particularly in children in parts of Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Covishield's viral vector technology is a key differentiator from other types of vaccines that might employ protein subunits or RBDs directly.

questions.text: Match the following institutions in Column A with their correct descriptions in Column B.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

1-b. Orphanages: While similar to foster homes in providing care, they are more specific to children without a home or parental care, unlike foster homes which include children who may eventually reunite with their family.

 

2-a. Foster Homes: Different from orphanages as these homes may focus more on temporary care or provide a path to reunification with biological families.

 

3-d. Adoption: Unlike foster care, adoption is a permanent legal arrangement that fully integrates the child into the family with legal rights.

 

4-c. Borstals: Specifically meant for boys over 16 with behavior issues, distinct from other juvenile care facilities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 1-b. Orphanages: Provide care for children who cannot be taken care of by their parents.
  • 2-a. Foster Homes: These homes place children under the care of trained personnel.
  • 3-d. Adoption: A legal process that confers full parental rights and responsibilities on adoptive parents.
  • 4-c. Borstals: Institutions meant for boys over the age of 16 who require training and reform due to behavioral issues.

 

Note:

 

Remand Homes: Institutions focused on mental and physical health support, often providing temporary housing and rehabilitation for children.

questions.text: Under which section of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) is the McNaughten's Rule defined?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Section 22 of BNS

 

  • The McNaughten's Rule is a legal standard that assesses criminal responsibility for individuals with mental disorders. It is defined under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), focusing on cases where a person may not be held criminally responsible if they were unable to understand the nature of their actions or distinguish right from wrong due to a mental illness. 
  • This rule is significant for insanity defenses in legal proceedings and helps determine if a defendant had the mental capacity to commit a crime intentionally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Section 84 of BNS: Section 84 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) does not relate to McNaughten’s Rule. Instead, it addresses the offense of enticing, taking away, or detaining a married woman with the intent to facilitate illicit intercourse. This provision is unrelated to mental health or criminal responsibility standards.

 

Option C. Section 122 of BNS: Section 122 of the BNS deals with causing hurt or grievous hurt due to sudden and grave provocation. It outlines a lighter punishment when the offense is committed without an intent to harm anyone other than the person who provoked them. This section is focused on physical harm due to provocation and does not pertain to insanity defenses or mental incapacity.

 

Option D. Section 184 of BNS: Section 184 of the BNS covers the use of a previously used government stamp with the intent to defraud or cause a loss to the government. It prescribes punishment for fraudulent reuse of stamps but has no relevance to criminal responsibility or mental health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The McNaughten's Rule, concerning the legal defense of insanity, is defined under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a continuous cell line used for viral culture?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) WI-38

 

  • WI-38 is a human embryonic lung cell line and is classified as a diploid cell line, meaning it has a finite number of divisions before it undergoes cellular senescence. 
  • It is not considered a continuous cell line because it does not divide indefinitely. 
  • WI-38 cells are primarily used for vaccine production and other research but are not suitable for long-term continuous culture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vero: Incorrect. Vero cells are derived from African green monkey kidney cells and are continuous cell lines, capable of dividing indefinitely. They are widely used for viral culture.

 

Option B. Hep2: Incorrect. Hep2 cells are derived from human laryngeal carcinoma and are a continuous cell line, often used in virology research for growing various viruses.

 

Option D. Hela: Incorrect. Hela cells, derived from human cervical carcinoma, are one of the first established continuous cell lines and are commonly used in various fields of research, including virology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • WI-38 is a diploid cell line with a limited lifespan, unlike continuous cell lines such as Vero, Hep2, and Hela, which can proliferate indefinitely in culture.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with difficulty chewing on one side. On examination, there is reduced movement of the mandible due to impaired muscle function. Which of the following nerves, a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Masseteric

 

  • The mandibular nerve (V3) is a mixed nerve, and its anterior division primarily gives motor branches to the muscles of mastication, along with one sensory branch (buccal nerve). 
  • The masseteric nerve, which arises from the anterior division, supplies the masseter muscle, a key muscle involved in chewing and jaw movement. 
  • Damage to this branch can impair mastication.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lingual: Although it is a branch of the mandibular nerve, the lingual nerve arises from the posterior division. It provides sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and does not contribute to the motor supply to the muscles of mastication.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal: This is another branch of the posterior division of the mandibular nerve. It carries sensory fibers to the auricle, temporal region, and temporomandibular joint. It does not supply motor innervation to the muscles of mastication.

 

Option D. Meningeal: The meningeal branch (nervus spinosus) is a branch of the mandibular nerve but is not part of the anterior division. It re-enters the skull via the foramen spinosum to provide sensory innervation to the dura mater.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The masseteric nerve is a motor branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve (V3) and supplies the masseter muscle, which is essential for mastication. 
  • The anterior division primarily provides motor branches to the muscles of mastication, with the exception of the buccal nerve, which is sensory.

questions.text: Which molecule is primarily responsible for transporting long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carnitine

 

  • Carnitine plays a pivotal role in the transport of long-chain fatty acids from the cytosol into the mitochondria, a critical step for beta-oxidation and energy production in cardiac muscle, particularly during fasting states when fatty acids serve as a major energy source.
     
    1. Transport Mechanism: Long-chain fatty acids are activated to fatty acyl-CoA in the cytosol. Carnitine facilitates their transfer into the mitochondria via the carnitine shuttle, which includes carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT-I) on the outer mitochondrial membrane and carnitine palmitoyltransferase II (CPT-II) on the inner mitochondrial membrane.
    2. Beta-Oxidation: Once inside the mitochondria, the fatty acyl-CoA undergoes beta-oxidation, producing acetyl-CoA, which enters the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle for ATP generation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CETP (Cholesteryl Ester Transfer Protein): CETP facilitates the transfer of cholesteryl esters and triglycerides between lipoproteins, such as HDL and LDL, and is not involved in fatty acid transport or beta-oxidation.

 

Option B. LCAT (Lecithin-Cholesterol Acyltransferase): LCAT esterifies free cholesterol to cholesteryl esters on HDL, aiding in reverse cholesterol transport. It has no role in fatty acid metabolism or mitochondrial transport.

 

Option D. Acyl carrier protein: Acyl carrier protein (ACP) is a component of the fatty acid synthase complex, involved in the synthesis (not degradation) of fatty acids. It is not related to the mitochondrial transport of fatty acids or beta-oxidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Carnitine facilitates the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria via the carnitine shuttle, enabling beta-oxidation for ATP production, especially in energy-demanding tissues like cardiac muscle.

questions.text: Based on the provided kinetic model, what type of inhibition is most likely depicted?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Non-competitive

 

  • In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to a site on the enzyme other than the active site. 
  • This binding induces a conformational change in the enzyme, reducing its catalytic activity.
  • Non-competitive inhibition decreases the maximum reaction velocity (Vmax) because the enzyme’s activity is reduced, but it does not affect the substrate binding affinity, leaving the Michaelis constant (Km) unchanged. 
  • The graph provided demonstrates these key features: a reduction in Vmax while Km remains constant.
  • Non-competitive inhibition cannot be overcome by increasing substrate concentration because the inhibitor affects the enzyme's function independently of substrate binding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Competitive: Competitive inhibition involves the inhibitor binding to the active site of the enzyme, competing with the substrate. This increases the Km but does not affect the Vmax. The graph does not show the hallmarks of competitive inhibition, such as increased Km.

 

Option C. Suicidal: Suicidal inhibition refers to irreversible enzyme inactivation through covalent binding. The graph represents reversible inhibition, not permanent enzyme inactivation.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to simultaneous decreases in both Km and Vmax. This pattern is not observed in the graph, which shows unchanged Km and reduced Vmax, characteristic of non-competitive inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds to an allosteric site, reducing enzyme activity regardless of substrate concentration. 
  • This leads to a decreased Vmax without altering Km.

choices.text: The case fatality rate for this disease is lower in women
The case fatality rate for this disease is higher in women
The duration of the disease is shorter in men
Risk factors for developing the disease are more common in women

questions.text: The incidence rate of a disease is five times higher in women than in men, but the prevalence rates are similar between the sexes. What is the most likely explanation for this observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The case fatality rate for this disease is higher in women

 

  • Prevalence (P) is determined by both the incidence (I) and the average duration (d) of the disease (P=I×d).
  •  In this scenario, if the incidence rate is five times higher in women but prevalence rates are the same for both sexes, it indicates that the duration of the disease (d) must be shorter in women. 
  • A shorter duration can result either from the disease being more fatal in women (higher case fatality rate) or the disease being more easily curable in women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The case fatality rate for this disease is lower in women: If the case fatality rate were lower in women, the disease would have a longer duration in women, leading to higher prevalence in women. This contradicts the given information that prevalence is equal between the sexes.

 

Option C. The duration of the disease is shorter in men: This would result in a lower prevalence in men, not equal prevalence between men and women, given that incidence is lower in men.

 

Option D. Risk factors for developing the disease are more common in women: This explains the higher incidence but does not account for the equal prevalence, which requires consideration of the disease's duration or fatality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When the incidence of a disease is significantly higher in one group, but prevalence remains the same, a shorter disease duration (due to higher case fatality or faster cure rates) in the group with higher incidence can explain the discrepancy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with known chronic renal and hepatic failure requires intubation for an elective surgery. Which of the following muscle relaxants is the most appropriate choice given his medical condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cis-atracurium

 

  • Cis-atracurium is the muscle relaxant of choice in patients with both renal and hepatic failure. 
  • Unlike other neuromuscular blockers, cis-atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination, a non-enzymatic process that occurs at physiological pH and temperature. 
  • This unique metabolism allows it to be safely used in patients with impaired renal or hepatic function, as its clearance does not depend on renal or hepatic pathways.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Vecuronium: Incorrect. Vecuronium is primarily eliminated via hepatic metabolism and to a lesser extent by the kidneys. In patients with hepatic or renal impairment, the use of vecuronium may lead to prolonged neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option C. Rocuronium: Incorrect. Rocuronium is predominantly metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys. In patients with renal or hepatic failure, the duration of action of rocuronium may be extended, making it less ideal.

 

Option D. Rapacuronium: Incorrect. Rapacuronium was withdrawn from the market due to severe side effects including bronchospasm. Even if it were available, its metabolism involving both liver and kidneys would make it unsuitable for patients with renal and hepatic failure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Cis-atracurium is the preferred muscle relaxant in patients with renal and hepatic failure due to its Hofmann elimination mechanism, which allows safe use regardless of renal or liver function status.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about clozapine are true?

 

  1. Most common side effect is sedation
  2. WBC monitoring is required weekly for first 6 months
  3. It has highest risk of metabolic syndrome among antipsychotics
  4. Agranulocytosis is a dose-dependent side effect
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3 are correct

 

1. Most common side effect is sedation: True. Sedation is the most common side effect of clozapine, often occurring due to its strong antihistaminergic and anticholinergic effects.

 

2. WBC monitoring is required weekly for first 6 months: True. This is correct; WBC and absolute neutrophil count (ANC) monitoring is mandatory weekly for the first 6 months to mitigate the risk of agranulocytosis.

 

3. It has the highest risk of metabolic syndrome among antipsychotics: True. Clozapine has the highest risk of metabolic side effects, including significant weight gain, dyslipidemia, and insulin resistance, compared to other antipsychotics.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Agranulocytosis is a dose-dependent side effect: False. Agranulocytosis is idiosyncratic and not dose-dependent. Its occurrence is unpredictable and unrelated to the dose of clozapine administered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clozapine is the drug of choice in treatment-resistant schizophrenia. 
  • It has strong affinity towards D4 and low affinity towards D2, which explains the lack of extrapyramidal side effects. 
  • It also acts as an antagonist at 5 HT2A, D1, D3 and ⍺-adrenergic receptors. Clozapine is the only antipsychotic that decreases the suicidal ideation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of solvent abuse presents with fatigue and frequent exposure to toluene. Laboratory tests reveal elevated hippuric acid in his urine. Hippuric acid is formed by the conjugation of which of the following compounds?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benzoyl glycine

 

  • Hippuric acid is a compound formed in the liver through the conjugation of benzoic acid with glycine.
  • This process occurs as part of the body’s detoxification pathway, particularly for substances like toluene, which is metabolized to benzoic acid. 
  • Benzoic acid undergoes conjugation via the enzyme glycine N-acyltransferase, leading to the formation of benzoyl glycine (hippuric acid). 
  • Hippuric acid is then excreted in the urine as a detoxified product.
  • Clinically, elevated hippuric acid levels can serve as a marker for toluene exposure, commonly seen in individuals with solvent abuse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benzoyl acetate: Benzoyl acetate does not participate in the metabolism of benzoic acid or in hippuric acid formation. It is not involved in the conjugation pathway with glycine.

 

Option C. Benzoyl lactate: Benzoyl lactate is not a known intermediate or product in the metabolic pathway of benzoic acid. Lactate is typically associated with anaerobic metabolism, not detoxification pathways.

 

Option D. Benzoyl glutamine: While glutamine is involved in ammonia detoxification and urea cycle processes, it does not conjugate with benzoic acid to form hippuric acid. The conjugating partner in this case is glycine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hippuric acid is formed by the conjugation of benzoic acid with glycine in the liver and is excreted in urine. 
  • It serves as a clinical marker for toluene exposure or benzoic acid metabolism.

choices.text: Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length Pair Technique

questions.text: Which of the following methods is most appropriate for quantitative analysis of the viral RNA genome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RT-PCR followed by Real-time PCR

 

  • For quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes, the gold standard method is RT-PCR followed by Real-time PCR, which combines:
    1. Reverse Transcription (RT): Converts viral RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcriptase.
    2. Real-time PCR: Amplifies the cDNA and measures the viral load in real time using fluorescence, enabling precise quantification of the RNA genome.
  • This combination is sensitive, specific, and widely used in clinical settings for RNA viruses like SARS-CoV-2, HCV, and HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nested PCR: Nested PCR is a two-step DNA amplification process used to improve specificity and sensitivity for DNA targets. It is not suitable for RNA quantification, as it does not include a reverse transcription step.

 

Option C. Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length Pair Technique: This technique amplifies DNA and analyzes restriction sites, but it is not quantitative and cannot detect RNA directly.

 

Option D. Quantitative PCR (qPCR): While qPCR can quantify DNA, it cannot analyze RNA genomes directly without a preceding reverse transcription step to convert RNA into cDNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate method for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes is RT-PCR followed by Real-time PCR, which combines reverse transcription to convert RNA into cDNA and real-time fluorescence-based quantification during amplification.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of persistent hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, and weight loss is diagnosed with advanced cancer. As part of his treatment, he undergoes a surgical procedure. Following surgery, he is fitted with the device shown in the image. What is the most likely surgical procedure he underwent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngectomy

 

  • The patient underwent a total laryngectomy, which involves removing the larynx and creating a permanent tracheostoma by bringing the trachea directly to the skin surface. 
  • This procedure is typically performed for advanced laryngeal cancer.

 

Key points:

 

  • After laryngectomy, the patient's ability to speak is compromised because the vocal cords are removed along with the larynx.
  • The device shown in the image is a tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP).
  • This device is used for voice rehabilitation. 
  • It is inserted between the trachea and the esophagus to allow airflow into the esophagus, enabling the patient to produce speech.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheostomy: A tracheostomy involves creating a temporary or permanent opening in the trachea but does not include removal of the larynx. It is typically used for airway management, not for advanced laryngeal cancer treatment.

 

Option C. Cricothyroidotomy: Cricothyroidotomy is an emergency airway procedure involving a temporary opening in the cricothyroid membrane. It is not a permanent solution or associated with voice rehabilitation.

 

Option D. Thyroidectomy: Thyroidectomy involves removal of the thyroid gland, commonly for thyroid cancer or goiter. It does not involve creating a tracheal opening or affect the larynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Laryngectomy involves removal of the larynx and creation of a permanent tracheostoma. 
  • Post-operatively, a tracheoesophageal prosthesis can be used for voice rehabilitation to enable speech.

questions.text: Which of the following is the safety muscle of larynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

The safety muscle of the larynx is the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, which is responsible for abducting (opening) the vocal cords and thus maintaining a patent airway. In the image, the region labeled "C" corresponds to the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

 

  • This muscle is crucial as its bilateral paralysis can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. It is termed the "safety muscle" of the larynx for this reason.

 

Other Options:

choices.text: High Vmax and lack of inhibition by G6P

questions.text: A researcher is studying an enzyme involved in glucose metabolism that is notably inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate (G6P). This enzyme is likely to exhibit which of the following characteristics in most body tissues?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low Km and low Vmax

 

  • Hexokinase has a low Km and low Vmax, which allows it to effectively phosphorylate glucose at low concentrations, making it ideal for most tissues that require consistent glucose utilization regardless of large fluctuations in glucose concentration. 
  • Its activity is inhibited by G6P to prevent excessive phosphorylation when glucose is abundant.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. High Km and inducibility: High Km and inducibility describe glucokinase, not hexokinase, which functions in a high glucose environment like the liver and pancreatic beta cells. 

 

Option C. High Vmax and lack of inhibition by G6P: High Vmax and lack of inhibition by G6P incorrectly describes glucokinase, which is not inhibited by G6P but does have a high Vmax. 

 

Option D. Inducibility and high tissue specificity: Inducibility and high tissue specificity are incorrect as hexokinase is not inducible and is found in most tissues, not specifically.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Learn the kinetic properties of hexokinase, including low Km and low Vmax, and its inhibition by G6P, critical for regulating glucose metabolism in most tissues.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with Ischemic heart disease is posted for Coronary artery bypass graft surgery. You want beat to beat blood pressure measurement intraoperatively to guide you through the hemodynamic changes. Which among the following is the ideal artery for invasive blood pressure measurement?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial

 

Radial artery is the most commonly used site for invasive arterial pressure monitoring because:

 

  1. Easily accessible and superficial.
  2. Allows continuous beat-to-beat BP monitoring.
  3. Low risk of complications.
  4. Collateral circulation is usually confirmed by Allen’s test, reducing risk of ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar: Usually not used as the primary site; smaller and deeper, harder to cannulate.

 

Option C. Brachial: Larger artery, more central, but higher risk of limb ischemia if thrombosis occurs; rarely first choice.

 

Option D. Femoral: Used when upper limb access not feasible, or for very high-risk cardiac patients, but higher infection and hematoma risk.

questions.solution:
Ans. B) TB

 

The chest X-ray shows bilateral upper lobe opacities, cavitary lesions, and fibrosis, which are classic radiological findings of pulmonary tuberculosis. The clinical presentation of chronic cough, weight loss, and fatigue further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergilloma: Typically appears as a rounded mass within a pre-existing cavity, often with an air crescent sign; the current X-ray shows more diffuse cavitary and fibrotic changes.

 

Option C. Carcinoma lung: Usually presents with a localized mass, possibly with associated collapse or effusion, rather than bilateral cavitation and fibrosis.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Characteristically shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy or reticulonodular opacities, less commonly cavitary upper lobe lesions.

Which characteristic forms the basis for categorizing streptococci according to the Lancefield system?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C-substance

 

  • The Lancefield classification system groups β-hemolytic streptococci into serogroups (A, B, C… up to V) based on the carbohydrate antigen present in the bacterial cell wall.
  • This carbohydrate antigen is called the C-substance (C-carbohydrate).
  • Example:
    • Group A = Streptococcus pyogenes
    • Group B = Streptococcus agalactiae

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein O:

 

  • Not related to Lancefield classification.
  • Glycoproteins may play a role in bacterial adhesion but not in streptococcal grouping.

 

Option C. Muramic acid: 

 

  • A universal component of peptidoglycan cell walls in all bacteria, not specific to streptococci.
  • Hence, not used for classification.

 

Option D. M-protein:

 

  • A major virulence factor of Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • Helps in resistance to phagocytosis and associated with rheumatic fever.
  • Important for typing within Group A streptococci, but not the basis of Lancefield grouping.

A 4-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents for a well-child check. She was evaluated 2 weeks ago for a rash in the diaper area. At that visit, the patient was found to have erythematous papules in the diaper area that spared the skin folds. Her symptoms improved with use of a petrolatum barrier ointment with every diaper change. Today, vital signs and physical examination are normal. Which of the following most likely contributed to this patient's prior skin findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered local skin pH

 

This infant had erythematous papules in the diaper area that spared skin folds, which improved with petrolatum barrier ointment—classic features of irritant diaper dermatitis. The main contributing factor is prolonged exposure to urine and feces, which raises the local skin pH, disrupting the acidic skin barrier and making the epidermis more susceptible to irritation. The elevated pH activates fecal enzymes (lipases and proteases) that break down the stratum corneum, leading to inflammation and erythema. Management includes frequent diaper changes, barrier creams, and maintaining proper hygiene to restore skin pH and prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormal keratin expression: Disorders like ichthyosis or keratinopathic epidermal disorders involve defective keratin production, causing scaling and barrier defects. These are genetic and chronic, rather than acute, and usually present with diffuse scaling.

 

Option C. Increased hapten sensitization: This occurs in allergic contact dermatitis, where small molecules (haptens) trigger an immune response. Allergic rashes often involve skin folds, have vesicles, and may recur with repeated exposure to the allergen.

 

Option D. Local bacterial colonization: Bacterial overgrowth (eg, Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus) can exacerbate diaper dermatitis, causing pustules or oozing. However, simple irritant diaper rash is primarily non-infectious, and secondary infection occurs only if the barrier is broken or the inflammation persists.
